Award.AwardTitle: Large-Area Synthesis and Carrier Transport and Dynamical Properties of Atomically Thin Two-Dimensional In2Se3
Award.AbstractNarration:
Nontechnical Description: The behavior of electrons in a solid material is central to electrical and optical characteristics of the material and plays a critical role in determining the performance of electronic and optoelectronic devices such as transistors, photodetectors, and solar cells. Recently, two-dimensional materials, with the thickness down to a single atomic layer, have emerged as a new class of material systems with novel properties beyond conventional bulk materials. This project studies the charge carrier transport and dynamics in a technologically important two-dimensional material, indium selenide, and develops a fundamental understanding of the synthesis-structure-property relation. The research is integrated into education and outreach activities. In addition to providing research opportunities for undergraduate and graduate students, including those from the underrepresented groups in science and engineering, the research results generated in this project are incorporated into the classroom teaching and hands-on experience with optics, electric circuits, and photovoltaics is offered to high school students through a summer workshop.

Technical Description: This research project aims to establish a fundamental understanding of charge carrier transport and ultrafast carrier dynamics in two-dimensional indium selenide. This project involves patterned synthesis of atomically thin single-crystal indium selenide over a large area using van der Waals epitaxy, and property characterizations utilizing a combination of transmission electron microscopy, confocal Raman spectroscopy, scanning probe microscopy, and spatially resolved ultrafast optical pump-probe techniques. This project addresses important issues in this material, particularly the transport properties and dynamics of both majority and minority charge carriers, and the correlation among the properties, structures, and material synthesis. The understanding of this synthesis-structure-property relation provides a fundamental materials science basis for innovative optoelectronic applications.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Intellectual Merit:

Indium selenide (In2Se3) is a material that can have different crystal structures (i.e. different structural phases). Two of these phases, α and β, have layered structures so that thin layers of In2Se3 can be isolated. These thin layers belong to the two-dimensional (2D) material family, which has attracted enormous research interests due to their unique properties. In this project, we have studied phase-specific electrical and thermal properties of 2D α- and β-In2Se3, and have explored the unique properties of phase-defined heterostructures that combine α- and β-In2Se3.

Specifically, our electrical measurements have shown that while α-In2Se3 is a semiconductor, β-In2Se3 behaves like a metal. Our studies have also revealed large contrast in thermal properties: the thermal conductivity of β-In2Se3 is much lower than that of α-In2Se3. Further investigations show that such a large difference originates from distinctive phonon (a quantum mechanical description of vibrations of atoms in the crystal lattice) characteristics in these two phases, as phonons play an important role in thermal transport. Particularly, we have found that, for α-In2Se3, the atomic displacements of most phonon modes exhibit well-defined directions and clear longitudinal/transverse nature; on the other hand, the phonon modes in β-In2Se3 show rather complex and mixed vibrational characteristics, indicating significant interaction between phonons. The stronger phonon-phonon interactions leads to suppressed thermal conductivity in β-In2Se3. 

The vastly different physical properties between these two phases motivated our further studies on phase-defined heterostructures. In vertically stacked α- and β-In2Se3 structures (i.e. vertical heterostructures), we discovered significantly enhanced thermoelectric power, indicating an efficient energy conversion from thermal power to electrical power. Efficient thermoelectric energy conversion, e.g. waste heat recovery, contributes to an energy-efficient society. We have also explored in-plane α- and β-In2Se3 structures (i.e. with α- and β-In2Se3 "stitched" together). Particularly, we used a laser beam to directly "write" β-phase patterns in α-In2Se3 layers, based on the optically activated solid-solid phase transitions. This novel approach is scalable and provides flexibility in defining different device structures. We further probed the charge carrier transport properties of the in-plane α-β junctions fabricated by this technique. By combining experimental results with detailed numerical simulations of device characteristics, we were able to elucidate the observed highly asymmetric carrier transport behaviors that cannot be explained by the conventional model.

Broader Impacts:

Knowledge derived from our studies paves the way to further explore new 2D heterostructure fabrication methods and novel device concepts that will impact our society in terms of energy conservations and the development of advanced technologies. This project has provided hands-on training opportunities for several PhD students and have prepared them well for their individual careers. In addition, we have developed a summer camp for kids with the Park and Recreation Department of Pullman that offered lectures and hands-on activities on optics, electricity, and photovoltaics.
